Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: A Cyber-Physical Infrastructure for the "Smart City"

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims at making cities "smarter" by engineering processes such as traffic control, efficient parking services, and new urban activities such as recharging electric vehicles. To that end, the research will study the components needed to establish a Cyber-Physical Infrastructure for urban environments and address fundamental problems that involve data collection, resource allocation, real-time decision making, safety, and security. Accordingly, the research is organized along two main directions: (i) Sensing and data acquisition using a new mobile sensor network paradigm designed for urban environments; and (ii) Decision Support for the "Smart City" relying on formal verification and certification methods coupled with innovative dynamic optimization techniques used for decision making and resource allocation. The work will bring together and build upon methodological advances in optimization under uncertainty, computer simulation, discrete event and hybrid systems, control and games, system security, and formal verification and safety. Target applications include: a "Smart Parking" system where parking spaces are optimally assigned and reserved, and vehicular traffic regulation.

The research has the potential of revolutionizing the way cities are viewed: from a passive living and working environment to a highly dynamic one with new ways to deal with transportation, energy, and safety. Teaming up with stakeholders in the Boston Back Bay neighborhood, the City of Boston, and private industry, the research team expects to establish new collaborative models between universities and urban groups for cutting-edge research embedded in the deployment of an exciting technological, economic, and sociological development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is aimed to develop tools for complex networked systems encountered in various infrastructures in a city environment.  There are two major advances being made during the course of the project.  The first one is on the security measure for data privacy in infrastructures such as power grids and hospitals. The idea is named as ``dynamic secrets" and can be explained briefly as follows. When a pair of wireless devices is communicating their exchanged data in the past can be used as the basis for security in the next period.  Such periods can be very short due to the high speed of modern wireless communication technologies. The eavesdroppers face insurmountable difficulties in breaking the secrets thus produced. The dynamic secrets scheme can also be generalized to wired environment via multi-path communications. It can also be seen that the mobility of the devices would help making the dynamic secret scheme easier to implement, as opposed to the other security schemes. A Springer book and a Wikipedia page h(ttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_secrets) have been published on the topic of dynamic secrets. 


The second advance is on the subject of similarity testing of complex networks.  The infrastructure systems are increasingly involving complex networks for communication and command. As such it is important to identify similar networks in order to compare the design and control of networks.  The similarity testing technique developed in this project converts the spatial structure of networks into time functions to facilitate comparisons. This is closely related to the similarity testing in image processing and in biology intelligence for concept abstraction algorithms.
